column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=III
#Text=MICHAEL IVANOVICH awoke early next morning .
#Text=He entered his brother ’s study , and handed him the cheque , filled in for a sum which he asked him to pay in monthly instalments to his daughter .
#Text=He inquired when the express left for St. Petersburg .
#Text=The train left at seven in the evening , giving him time for an early dinner before leaving .

#Text=He breakfasted with his sister-in-law , who refrained from mentioning the subject which was so painful to him , but only looked at him timidly ; and after breakfast he went out for his regular morning walk .
#Text=Alexandra Dmitrievna followed him into the hall .
#Text=“ Go into the public gardens , Michael -- it is very charming there , and quite near to Everything , ” said she , meeting his sombre looks with a pathetic glance .

#Text=Michael Ivanovich followed her advice and went to the public gardens , which were so near to Everything , and meditated with annoyance on the stupidity , the obstinacy , and heartlessness of women .
#Text=“ She is not in the very least sorry for me , ” he thought of his sister-in-law .
#Text=“ She cannot even understand my sorrow .
#Text=And what of her ? ”
#Text=He was thinking of his daughter .
#Text=“ She knows what all this means to me -- the torture .
#Text=What a blow in one ’s old age !
#Text=My days will be shortened by it !
#Text=But I ’d rather have it over than endure this agony .

#Text=And all that ‘ pour les beaux yeux d’un chenapan’ -- oh ! ” he moaned ; and a wave of hatred and fury arose in him as he thought of what would be said in the town when every one knew . ( And no doubt every one knew already . ) Such a feeling of rage possessed him that he would have liked to beat it into her head , and make her understand what she had done .
#Text=These women never understand .
#Text=“ It is quite near Everything , ” suddenly came to his mind , and getting out his notebook , he found her address .
#Text=Vera Ivanovna Silvestrova , Kukonskaya Street , Abromov ’s house .
#Text=She was living under this name .
#Text=He left the gardens and called a cab .
#Text=“ Whom do you wish to see , sir ? ” asked the midwife , Maria Ivanovna , when he stepped on the narrow landing of the steep , stuffy staircase .
#Text=“ Does Madame Silvestrova live here ? ”
#Text=“ Vera Ivanovna ?
#Text=Yes ; please come in .
#Text=She has gone out ; she ’s gone to the shop round the corner .
#Text=But she ’ll be back in a minute . ”

#Text=Michael Ivanovich followed the stout figure of Maria Ivanovna into a tiny parlour , and from the next room came the screams of a baby , sounding cross and peevish , which filled him with disgust .
#Text=They cut him like a knife .
#Text=Maria Ivanovna apologised , and went into the room , and he could hear her soothing the child .
#Text=The child became quiet , and she returned .
#Text=“ That is her baby ; she ’ll be back in a minute .
#Text=You are a friend of hers , I suppose ? ”
#Text=“ Yes -- a friend -- but I think I had better come back later on , ” said Michael Ivanovich , preparing to go .
#Text=It was too unbearable , this preparation to meet her , and any explanation seemed impossible .
#Text=He had just turned to leave , when he heard quick , light steps on the stairs , and he recognised Lisa ’s voice .
#Text=“ Maria Ivanovna -- has he been crying while I ’ve been gone -- I was -- ”
#Text=Then she saw her father .
#Text=The parcel she was carrying fell from her hands .
#Text=“ Father ! ” she cried , and stopped in the doorway , white and trembling .
#Text=He remained motionless , staring at her .
#Text=She had grown so thin .
#Text=Her eyes were larger , her nose sharper , her hands worn and bony .
#Text=He neither knew what to do , nor what to say .
#Text=He forgot all his grief about his dishonour .
#Text=He only felt sorrow , infinite sorrow for her ; sorrow for her thinness , and for her miserable rough clothing ; and most of all , for her pitiful face and imploring eyes .
#Text=“ Father -- forgive , ” she said , moving towards him .
#Text=“ Forgive -- forgive me , ” he murmured ; and he began to sob like a child , kissing her face and hands , and wetting them with his tears .
#Text=In his pity for her he understood himself .
#Text=And when he saw himself as he was , he realised how he had wronged her , how guilty he had been in his pride , in his coldness , even in his anger towards her .
#Text=He was glad that it was he who was guilty , and that he had nothing to forgive , but that he himself needed forgiveness .
#Text=She took him to her tiny room , and told him how she lived ; but she did not show him the child , nor did she mention the past , knowing how painful it would be to him .
#Text=He told her that she must live differently .
#Text=“ Yes ; if I could only live in the country , ” said she .
#Text=“ We will talk it over , ” he said .
#Text=Suddenly the child began to wail and to scream .
#Text=She opened her eyes very wide ; and , not taking them from her father ’s face , remained hesitating and motionless .
#Text=“ Well -- I suppose you must feed him , ” said Michael Ivanovich , and frowned with the obvious effort .
#Text=She got up , and suddenly the wild idea seized her to show him whom she loved so deeply the thing she now loved best of all in the world .
#Text=But first she looked at her father ’s face .
#Text=Would he be angry or not ? His face revealed no anger , only suffering .
#Text=“ Yes , go , go , ” said he ; “ God bless you . Yes .
#Text=I ’ll come again to-morrow , and we will decide .
#Text=Good-bye , my darling -- good-bye . ” Again he found it hard to swallow the lump in his throat .
